steps.title: Scrub potatoes and rinse well with cold water.
steps.content: Scrub potatoes and rinse well with cold water.

steps.title: Remove excess moisture by drying potatoes with a clean tea towel or white paper towels, if baking in a conventional oven.
steps.content: Remove excess moisture by drying potatoes with a clean tea towel or white paper towels, if baking in a conventional oven.

steps.title: Cut off any bruised or bad spots, if required.
steps.content: Cut off any bruised or bad spots, if required.

steps.title: Pierce the potatoes once or twice with a fork.
steps.content: Pierce the potatoes once or twice with a fork. This will allow for faster, more even cooking.

steps.title: Rub the potatoes with olive oil to coat evenly.
steps.content: Rub the potatoes with olive oil to coat evenly. (optional). Season with salt and pepper. Place the potatoes on a baking tray or roasting dish (optional). (Some people prefer to put the potato directly onto the wire rack.)

steps.title: Bake potatoes at 425 °F (218 °C) for 45 to 60 minutes.
steps.content: Bake potatoes at 425 °F (218 °C) for 45 to 60 minutes. [2] X Research source [3] X Research source Potatoes are done when they can be pierced easily with a fork. Potatoes may also be baked at lower temperatures for longer times. This process tends to give the outside of the spud a crisper skin. [2] X Research source 350 °F (177 °C) for approximately 90 minutes or 375 °F (191 °C) for approximately 75 minutes is a good guideline. Cooking times will vary. Not all potatoes are uniform in size and mass, making these cooking times a guideline , not a rule . Perform the fork test to figure out if the potato has reached the doneness you want.

steps.title: Season and garnish as necessary.
steps.content: Season and garnish as necessary. Some classic combinations include: Sour cream and chive Butter and salt Cheese

steps.title: Season the potatoes with olive oil, salt and pepper (optional).
steps.content: Season the potatoes with olive oil, salt and pepper (optional). If you're not going to do anything with the baked potato after it's cooked, seasoning it with olive oil, salt and pepper might be a good idea.

steps.title: Wrap the potatoes in aluminum foil.
steps.content: Wrap the potatoes in aluminum foil. Aluminum foil is a good conductor of heat, meaning that the cooking time on baked potatoes wrapped in aluminum foil will probably go down. If you like baked potatoes with crispy skins, however, look out: wrapping in aluminum foil creates a potato with skin that is more steamed than crispy. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Bake at 425 °F (218 °C) for ~45 to 60 minutes, or 400 °F (204 °C) for 60 to 70 minutes.
steps.content: Bake at 425 °F (218 °C) for ~45 to 60 minutes, or 400 °F (204 °C) for 60 to 70 minutes. Slower-cooked baked potatoes often have a creamier center. Check the potato for doneness slightly before you think it may be finished cooking. Because the aluminum foil accelerates the cooking, you may want to check early to avoid an overdone potato.

steps.title: Place the potatoes in a microwave-safe dish and microwave on high for 5 minutes.
steps.content: Place the potatoes in a microwave-safe dish and microwave on high for 5 minutes.

steps.title: Turn the potatoes over and microwave for an additional 3 to 5 minutes.
steps.content: Turn the potatoes over and microwave for an additional 3 to 5 minutes.

steps.title: Check for doneness.
steps.content: Check for doneness. If potato is still not fully cooked, continue microwaving potato in 1 minute intervals until fully cooked.

steps.title: Scrub potatoes but do not dry.
steps.content: Scrub potatoes but do not dry. A little moisture will make for a better baked potato after it has finished cooking.

steps.title: Place in slow cooker, cover, and cook on low for 6 to 8 hours or until tender.
steps.content: Place in slow cooker, cover, and cook on low for 6 to 8 hours or until tender. This method will produce the softest-skinned, lightest potato. Cooking at very low heat for longer times will minimize the risk of overcooking.
